Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Network Infrastructure: CADIS -- Cyberinfrastructure Advancing Data-Interactive Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern scientific research often involves the marshaling of very large data sets through extensive processing pipelines before usable information can be extracted. Examples of this type of data-intensive research include the near real-time analysis of time-varying medical images, decoding the genetic structure of diverse biological systems, simulating the merger of binary star systems, modeling complex flow structures in chemical reaction tanks, and determining how to effectively interact with extraordinarily high-resolution lunar and planetary data.

The CADIS project provides the critical networking infrastructure that enables this wide range of data-intensive research activities at Louisiana State University (LSU). CADIS links high-performance computer systems located on campus and at other state and national facilities to a new state-of-the-art building at LSU -- the Louisiana Digital Media Center (LDMC). Serving as a center for diverse, data-intensive research activities, the LDMC houses high resolution display technologies and custom visualization systems and is dedicated to digital computation, media production, and advanced teaching methods. CADIS enhances student learning experiences by facilitating the use of actual data sets from experimental instruments and large-scale computational simulations, and the classroom application of novel visualization methods. CADIS also is expected to open new opportunities for collaboration between LSU researchers and the growing digital media industry across Louisiana.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CADIS project established a high-bandwidth network connecting scientists located in the Louisiana Digital Media Center (DMC), with the high-performance computing (HPC) systems of the Louisiana State University (LSU) and the Louisiana Optical Network Initiative (LONI) network. It involved installation of a Juniper MX960 aggregation router in the LSU Frey Computing Services Center, and 3 40 Gbps fiber optic links to the DMC. Within the DMC building, a 40 Gbps fiber optic link was established from the machine room to a server driving a 4K HD digital projector to support display of digital graphics, such as digital special effects and animations, and large scale scientific visualizations of research data, such as gravitational wave generation from coalescing black holes or hurricane storm surge modeling. 4K HD provides 4 times the resolution of standard high definition television.

The Juniper switch supports 40 Gbps connections to two of the LSU HPC systems, SuperMike-II and SuperMIC, as well as a 40 Gbps connection to the LONI QB2 HPC system. During testing, the server was shown to be capable of sustaining a 37.2 Gbps data rate (measured with a diagnostic tool called iperf3) while running 3 simultaneous data flows to three HPC systems.  This allows scientist to move large volumes of data quickly between the computational resources, and various post-processing uses in the DMC. In addition, it provides a dedicated 100 Gbps link to Internet2, giving researchers the ability to share large data sets with national and international collaborators. It supports the SuperMIC cluster with access to XSEDEnet, the national network connecting the major computational resources of NSF's Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment. 

The major problems overcome could best be described as equipment not operating up to it's advertised specifications. Failures to achieve  stated bandwidth specifications required extensive testing to prove that the problems lay in the networking hardware, and not with computer equipment proper at either end, or with the interconnecting fiber.  The network did not reach design specifications until the vendors provided new hardware. It's worth noting that this hardware had not been available at the time of initial purchase. This included network adapters that were installed in the server and clusters, and a switch line card.

A conclusion taken away from the deployment effort is that interoperability of 40 Gbps Ethernet is still on the cutting edge and may present significant obstacles in a particular situation.

The use of the CADIS network is evolving to support new capabilities for researchers in the DMC. One initial application is moving 4KHD videos, generated by applications running on the large clusters, to the projection system in the building's theater. These include videos staged directly from shared memory buffers, such as might be produced by running applications; and remote 4K visualizations from the Melete cluster running the Avizo software (Ullmer, Butler, et al., CNS 1126739). It is anticipated that terabytes of genomics data will eventually move over the network to Melete, or other DMC clusters, from various computation and data sources to allow interactive analysis and visualization. Specifically, a related NSF-supported effort is enabling real-time visualization of planetary databases, allowing researchers to explore terrains and features built from images and data taken from multiple sources (Kooima, CNS 1456638). One example would be overlaying thermal sensor data on realistic renderings of the moon's surface. When used in a classroom, such viewing will have much more impact on students than simply having them look at flat images in a textbook.
